title: Inside the fall of Teneo's ‘dark arts' PR master
text:
Teneo's top spin master gets trapped in the news cycle

It took Declan Kelly and Doug Band a decade to build Teneo into the go-to advisory group for CEOs looking to navigate — or, better still, avoid — a career-threatening reputational crisis. 

But within six months, both were hit with the types of calamity they tried to help their clients see off, costing them their jobs and throwing the future of the company into doubt.

Some DD readers may have never heard of Teneo until now, but they've certainly come across CVC Capital Partners, the private equity firm that invested $450m into the company, and the roster of A-listers who it depends on for advice. 

Among its special advisers in the US are Ginni Rometty, recently released from IBM, Ursula Burns, the former Xerox chief executive, and Andrew Liveris, the one-time Dow Chemical boss who sits on the board of Saudi Aramco. Former cabinet members like William Hague and Amber Rudd, are among those opening doors for it in the UK. 

Band, a former aide to Bill Clinton, brought A-list Washington connections, while Kelly had an Irish-American network and a talent for wooing CEOs of big companies from Coca-Cola to General Motors. 

That let them charge eye-popping monthly retainers of $250,000 to $1m even outside the times when clients were in the midst of a deal or a scandal. And as the fees grew, so did their company, to 1,250 people and almost $400m in revenues. 

Together they generated the sort of publicity that most public relations groups try to shy away from. 

It was an interview with Vanity Fair, where Band described his bitter break-up with the Clintons, which would ultimately be his downfall. 

Meanwhile, Kelly's departure was triggered by his behaviour at a celebrity event hosted by Global Citizen, a non-profit that aims to eradicate world poverty, where he is alleged to have inappropriately touched six women. Kelly, who sits on the charity's board and is close to its founder Hugh Evans, was swiftly removed from his post.

Yet as detailed in this Big Read by the FT's Andrew Edgecliffe-Johnson and DD's Arash Massoudi, Ortenca Aliaj, James Fontanella-Khan and Sujeet Indap, trouble was brewing behind closed doors at Teneo long before the allegations of Kelly's misconduct surfaced.

CVC had been split over the reputational risks of investing in Teneo, the story reveals, and some of its sharper-elbowed tactics had become fodder for lawsuits.  

A court case stemming from Anthem's $54bn bid for rival health insurer and Teneo client Cigna best encapsulates Teneo's methods: the presiding Delaware judge noted the group was “skilled in the darker arts of influencing the media and public discourse” following its attempt to sabotage the deal.

Teneo had conducted a “covert communications campaign”, the judge said, publicly maintaining that the deal was on track while leaking documents showing the opposite was true. (Teneo also went hunting for a back issue of Cigar Aficionado magazine which featured Anthem's chief executive smoking, which it hoped would “hurt his credibility as a healthcare CEO”.)

But none of Teneo's tactics managed to prevent Kelly's indiscretions from becoming public. 

As one executive put it: “He had a stable of experts who could have dealt with this in a more effective way; instead he opted for a cover-up.”

Teneo still has a deep bench of experts, as it has hastened to assure clients, but they may first need to explain why Teneo failed to emerge from its own reputational crisis unscathed. 

Elliott plays hardball in boardroom battle with GSK 

In April we told you that activist investor Elliott Management took a multibillion-pound stake in GlaxoSmithKline.

On Thursday Elliott called on GSK to refresh its board with new directors and launch a process to decide whether it's chief Emma Walmsley is fit to lead the company.

Elliott's 17-page letter to GSK, the hedge fund's first public confirmation of its stake in the healthcare company since the FT broke the news months ago, criticises “years of under-management” for its poor share price performance.

“Allowing GSK's long-term operational and share-price underperformance to persist without urgently taking appropriate measures would disappoint all with an interest in the company. The board must rise to the challenge and put forth a more ambitious plan to close the gap,” Elliott wrote to GSK chair Jonathan Symonds.

Walmsley has pushed back against such criticisms, telling the FT's Hannah Kuchler in an interview last week that she was a “change agent” committed to transforming GSK into an innovative home for breakthrough medicines.

Since that interview she has refused to answer questions about her leadership, but as Elliott ratchets up the pressure, Walmsley may soon be forced to acknowledge the elephant in the room.

Define ‘conflict of interest'

Omitting information isn't a crime.

Just ask Europe's largest software company SAP, which declined to disclose that its billionaire chair and biggest shareholder, Hasso Plattner, had a personal connection to a joint venture announced earlier this year worth hundreds of millions of euros.

The deal in question, a spin-off of SAP's financial services arm between SAP and the Munich-based private equity firm Dediq, also involved one more secret investor: the Hasso Plattner Foundation.

The stake had been a secret, until the FT and the German business paper Handelsblatt reported its existence in May. At the time, SAP and the foundation insisted it was all a fuss about nothing.

Now that it's all out in the open, the $145bn company has promised to no longer do deals with Plattner's foundation, and the foundation has agreed to divest its stake in the controversial joint venture, the FT's Joe Miller and Kadhim Shubber tell us.

After pressure from investors and investigations by Duff & Phelps and Gleiss Lutz — who SAP said found that all was above board — the tone is now somewhat different. 

And it seems that Platter's foundation has also changed its tune: “We recognise . . . that what is legally correct may not always be legitimate in the eyes of all stakeholders,” it said.

Job moves

  • Khalid al-Dabbagh is stepping down as chief financial officer of Saudi Aramco. He will be replaced by Ziad al-Murshed, Bloomberg reported.

  • Kantar, the global market data business owned by the private equity group Bain Capital, has hired Chris Jansen as its chief executive. He was previously chief of education group Cognita.

  • Allen & Overy has hired Hendrik Röhricht as a partner of the firm's private equity practice. He joins from Weil, Gotshal & Manges.

  • Fintech group Taulia has appointed Ali Ansari as director of global supply chain and payables solutions in London. He joins from HSBC.

  • Shearman & Sterling announced 18 counsel promotions.

  • Law firm Baker McKenzie named 95 partners. 

Smart reads 

Media buzz MailOnline's penchant for controversial clickbait has rocketed what used to be an insurance policy afterthought for the Mail's owner Lord Rothermere into a gossip-mongering moneymaking machine. It may have outgrown its declining parent publication. (FT)

Performative activism (and activewear) Days after the murder of George Floyd, a high-level Lululemon manager told her design team to put “all lives matter” atop the Canadian retailer's website. A reckoning over the company's alleged culture of racism soon followed. (Business Insider)

Selling out The hottest stock on Robinhood could soon be its own, as the trading platform prepares to set aside 35 per cent of shares in its upcoming IPO for its users. The timing isn't a coincidence, as public offerings are on track for their busiest summer in years. (Wall Street Journal)
